div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Creme Natural and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: THE TRANSVAAL CONSTITUTION.
div.p:
The mere fact that the decision on the constitutional issue in the Travel has at last been announced, that some sort of settlement has been decided upon, and that the settlement, such as it is, is to be put into effect without delay has been received with a general feeling of relief both in South Africa and in England. There are many features in that settlement, says the "Times," which are very far from satisfactory, and can only give rise to the gravest apprehensions as to, their eff.ot upon the political and material welfare of the colony. Bat, on the whole, the verdict seems to be that things might well have been worse. It would be sheer irony to interpret this attitude of acquiescence as a testimony to the statesmanship of the Government. On the contrary, it only throws into stronger relief the unwisdom of the line of action pursued during the last six months, of the policy of interference and menace from which any avenue of escape is welcome, however grest the risks that may attend it. There is nothing in this acquiescence which can diminish the force of the weighty argumenta brought forward by Lord Milner and the leaders of the Opposition, or reflect adversely upon their deliberate refusal to accept any part of the responsibility for a step which is not only open to grave doubt as regards the detail of its execution, but which they are firmly convinced ought not to have

been taken at all in the present condition of South Africa. It was, no doubt, very easy and natural for Mr. Churchill to conclude his speech on Tuesday by a plausible appeal to the Opposition to join the Government in giving a national sanction to their policy. But when wa consider the whole past attitude of the present Government towards the South African policy of their predecessors policy of which it can at least be said that it was dictated by no thought of making party capital out of a momentous Imperial issue when we remember the absolute refusal of the Prime Minister to accord the Opposition any information whatever, either as to the report of Sir West Ridgeway's Committee or as to the Government's intentions, or to provide any adequate facilities for the discussion of so vital and intricate a problem, it is difficult to treat that appeal otherwise than as an amazing piece of disingenuous droitness

Whatever decision the Government may yet come to as regards the Orange River Colony and the problem of land settlement, the issue in the Transvaal is now, in the main, one for the people of that colony to decide. The Boers have been put into a position in which no conquered people have ever been placed before. Within four years of a bitter and devastating struggle, brought about by their own determination to risk everything rather than give the merest vestige of political rights to the British majority in their country, they are now put in a position of equality, and more than equality, with their conquerors. We can only hope that they will follow the advice given them by their friends on the Continent, respond to the generous treatment meted out to them, and show their good sense and moderation by a whole hearted aad loyal acceptance of British institutions, an acceptance which is in no way inconsistent with vigorous defence of the interests of their race. As for the British element in the population of the Transvaal we cannot but regret that they should have been handicapped to an extent which may seriously endanger the maintenance of British supremacy in the colony and consequently in South Africa. But that very fact does undoubtedly create for them a great occasion to prove their mettle, to show in the political contest of the future the same earnestness, unity of purpose, and steadfastness that they showed in the anxious and trying period which preceded the war, and the same loyal 'self-sacrificing devotion alike to South Africa and to the Imperial ideal which they displayed on many hard-fought field. From now onwards the whole fate or destiny of South Africa is largely in their hands. With the knowledge of that responsibility resting upon them, with the consciousness of their own good right and of their own past efforts and achievements, with the vision of the future prosperity and greatness of a South Africa developed in accordance with British ideals, let them proceed with the difficult task which lies before them. The hearts of all lovers of South Africa and of all believers in our Imperial destiny will be with them in their endevour.

Polloemen Sent to Prison,

A council of discipline held at the Alex- andria Gouvernorat has condemned Soleiman G Mastapha and Abd-el Latif Issawi, privates It in the police, to 6 months' imprisonment with ti hard labour and to receive 35 lashes each for submitting false reports.
The Attarin Tragedy.

The Italian Consular Court at Alexandria h yesterday finished its preliminary enquiry into the circumstances attending the murder of Dr. Vavaropoulos. The documents of the case will be despatched to the Assize Court at Ancona, where Pierini will be tried.
Cheek Co-operation.

Since the conclusion of the new Greco- Egyptian Convention a janissary of the Helle- nic Consulate General has been placed at the disposal of the Commandant of Police at Cairo 1 and Alexandria to facilitate the working of the new law concerning gambling dens, etc.
Judicial Aid for the Poor.

A meeting will be held next week of a number of Alexandrian medical men to discos rome questions arising out of the murder of Dr. Vavaropoulo. It is proposed to appoint special doctors to each quarter for the public service and to give free medical advice to the poor.
Did Egypt's Postal System.

A most valuable document was found st Oxyrhynchus during the excavations last sea- son. It is in the shape of a minute or note by the local postman, noting that he has deliver- ed, among other things, "One roll of papyrus for Antiochas the Cretan, one roll for the King. and two letters for Apollonius the diabetes," thereby showing how well organized even village life was in Ptolemaic Egypt.
Sudden Deaths.

A Sudanese, aged 45, was found dead last night at Furn el Karkasb, in the Custom- house quarter. His body was removed to hospital for post mortem examination. Death was due to heart failure. A Berbere of 25 years died yesterday evening while going in a cab to visit a friend of his. His sudden death is attributed to over-indulgence in hashish and opium smoking. The body was removed to hospital.
All Saints' Church, Cairo.
In the absence of the Very Rev. Dean Butcher, the Rev. J. Thompson Burns, M. A, will be in charge of the Church and will reside at Church House, Sharia Madabagh.

div.head: GERMANY AND EGYPT
ENTENTE WITH ENGLAND.
div.p: An important article appeared on the 2nd inst. in the "Deutsche Revae" on Anglo-German relations from the pen of a writer who is intimately acquainted with the views entertained T on this subject by Prince von Bülow and the Foreign Office authorities. He observes that the approaching meeting between King Edward da and the Emperor William should pave the way to a better understanding, but that it does not signify in itself an understanding. In recent years German policy has been compelled to refrain from supporting or promoting British interests because British policy has sought to baulk every effort made by the Emperor to facilitate the expansion of German interests abroad.

It is probable, says the writer, that the er British Government will request in the near w fotore the assent of the German Government by to Lord Cromer's programme for the abolition in of the ex-territorial rights of foreigners in E.ypt m and of the co-operation of European diplomacy oc ha in certain questions connected with the country. But in the Anglo-German Convention of June, 1904, concluded, it may be remembered, at the moment of King Edward's visit to Kiel, it pe is expressly stipulated that the British Govern- by ment has no intention of making any change. be If the proposals were carried into effect it would the signify an alteration of the status quo, and as sh they take no account of the greatness of w German interests in Egypt, but suggest that co the English, French, and Italian languages g shall be equally admissible in the projec-ac ted Legislative Council and Courts of Jus th tice, it is difficult to see why the authorities fo in Berlin should consent to renounce their fo Treaty rights. Germany in this question must or insist on the equal treatment of Germans and C British in Egypt, and she must consider care- fally whether it is possible for her to fulfil any British wish so long-as the British Govern- of ment is impervious to the desires cherished by ti her in respect cf a terminus on the Persian Galf for the Bagdad Railway.

"If Great Britain," the writer proceeds, a "persists in making the Persian Gulf Mare 5 Clausum Britannicum, and in thus converting the question into one of might then Germany must treat British wishes with the same mea-

The writer goes on to observe that King Edward, as long as he lives, will remain the soul of the Anglo French entente, and that Germany conscquently must be prepared in the event of differences either with Great Britain or with France to find herself confronted by both Powers. But he characteristically remarks "the entente cannot be considered to embody ady elements of permanence since it is based r on the principle of disposing of foreign pro- perty and of ignoring existing treaties and on the tendency which is opposed to the preserva- tion of the status quo in Europe." "Such an alliance as this," he exclaims,"contains too, much inflammable material to be of long dura tion."

He further suggests that if the British Government, secure in the support of France, Italy, and Russia, should adopt in their entirety Lord Cromer's proposals, a situation might conceivably arise in which it would be incumbent on Germany to propose, as she did A in regard to Morocco last year, an International S Conference on Egyptian affairs to be convened i by the Sultan.

The writer hopes, however, that a solution E of the difficulty will be found through the usual, diplomatic channels. Meanwhile, and o until the diplomatic disarmament of Great d Britain and France has been effected, Germany, the says, must absolutely decline to listen to the siren tones of Sir Henry Campbell-Banner- min in favour of military disarmament.

div.head: PURIFICATION OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: This morning, the Italian Consular Court at Alexandria sentenced an Italian young man to eighteen days' imprisonment for attempting to hinder the police of the Morality Depart- ment of the Gouvernorat in their attempts to arrest a well-known local demi-mondaine. During the last few days these police have been carefully patrolling Nebi Daniel-street as Pit is believed that some private houses in that quarter are occupied by women whose charac- ters are not above suspicion.

div.head: PRISON LABOUR IN EGYPT.
div.p: According to the report for 1905 of the Director of Prison Industries, the industrial department has fully maintained the activity of previous years. On goods actually made and sold to the department there is an increase of LE 2,60, to other departments over £700, and to the public L.E. 1,400. As the public realize the value of prison work t and increase their orders, it is only reasonable 0- to expect that other Government departments 0 will eventually follow the example. The result h of prisoners' labour during the year is a profit 5 of L.B 13,5:0, after deducting the pay of instructors, &sistants, ghuffirs and other per- n sons engaged in manufacture, amounting to L.E. 5,676, which in the prisons of other coun- tries is not set off against labour. Nor have they any debit for wear and tear of implemente, etc., as in these accounts, to the extent of £2,000.

div.head:
SUEZ'S DANGER.
BRITISH GARRISON WANTED.
THE CHRISTIANS' PLIGHT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,-In your leading article of yesterday's date, "The Situation in Egypt," in which you refer to the letter written by an ex officer of the Egyptian Police to the "Daily Graphic' of recent date, I, in conjunction with a large number of Europeans of all classes in Suez, would like to point out that we perfectly agree with the above-mentioned letter-in that a small garrison of British troops should be stationed in such towns as Tantah, Zagazig, etc., and, in the light of recent events (Akaba crisis in particular !), in which practically the whole of the native population of Suez, led by numerous better educated Arabs, were loud in denouncing all Christians, threatening to massacre them, etc., and on more than one occasion it only wanted a very little spark to have set the town on fire!

Why therefore should an isolated town like Suez be left entirely at the mercy of such people with only a few Arab police (officered by the same class) to guard us 1 Should there be a rising they would undoubtedly side with the populace, according to their religion. Why should not Saez (including Port Tewfik), which has a very large European population in comparison to its size, have a small British garrison of say 250 men? There is splendid accommodation for more than that number in the Victoria Barracks, which has been allowed for a good many years to go to rack and rain for want of occupation. I would also point out there are no British troops nearer than Cairo, some hundreds of miles away: also we have no man of war here: that Saez Town is isolated from that of Port Tewfik (a distance of 3 miles), and also that the British population is far greater than that of Tantah or Zagazig and far more isolated. Either of these places could be supplied with troops in a couple of hours, whereas it would take 4 or 5 hours to bring them to Suez ! Ergo, every- one could be massacred at that time. Considering that the garrison is to be increased in Egypt, why not send us a small garrison? it would not be of any more expense to the Government whether they are stationed at Cairo or Suez. Accommodation is already here. No additional expense on that moore. Supplies could be obtained here as cheap as at Cairo. The place is healthy, etc.

A petition to Lord Cromer has already been suggested, but as his Lordship is away in England, that has been adjourned until his return: but we trust that the above letter may have the desired effect by its being brought to the notice of the powers that be. Trusting that I am not encroaching too much on your limited space.-I am, etc.,

div.head: THE BRITISH GARRISON.
div.p: In the House of Commons last week, Mr. J. M. Robertson (Tyneside) asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs what is the amount of Egypt's contribution to the maintenance of the army of occupation in Egypt; what was the proportion of that to the whole cost; what were the respective increases of cost, British and Egyptian, in consequence. of the reinforcement of the army of occupation; and what the strength of the force was now to be.

Mr. Ranciman (Dewsbury), replying for Sir E. Grey (Northumberland, Berwick): The pre- sent contribution is £100 000 a year, which represents approximately the extra cost of the force in Egypt, before the recent increase, over its cost at home, which would be about £275,000. The future strength of the force will be about 5,700, but the future contribution is at present under consideration.

div.head: THE COLDSTREAM GUARDS.
div.p: Lord R. Cecil (Marylebone, E), on behalf of Sir S. Scott (Marylebone, W.), asked the Secretary of State for War last week whether the condemned battalion of the Coldstream Guards was to sail for Egypt in October, and whether the Government intended that the whole of the exceptional expense which would be necessarily incurred by married officers, non-commissioned officers, and men, owing to moving for one year, was to fall upon the battalion, or whether the Government was prepared to contribute towards this exceptional expenditure.
Mr. Haldane.-This battalion will go to Egypt on September 29. No decision has been come to to treat this battalion in respect of the expenses of their move differently from other infantry battalions.
EXCAVATIONS AT ALEXANDRIA.

The committee of the Museum have applied for a credit of LE. 200 for continuing their works of excavation and restoration; the funds previously available having been absorbed by various works, such as the reserves at Chatby Necropolis, the restoration of Kom el- Shougafs, etc.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Alexandria (Westcott and Laurance Lire) left Tripoli yesterday, and is due here next Monday with general cargo from Antwerp and London.

div.head: EGYPTIAN PATRIOT.
div.p: THE TOLERATION OF ENGLAND:

The tolerance with which England has permitted Mustapha Pasha Kamel to exercise his profession as an Anglophobe agitator in the capital of the Empire has aroused tributes to our broad-mindedness from the Continental Press, who are well aware that Prance would never permit an Algerian or a Tunisian Moslem agitator to come to Paris to agitate against her civilizing mission in North Africa, while the spectacle of a Herero trying to organise an agitation at Berlin against Germany's colonial methods is absolutely inconceivable.

The "Journal" of Geneva says:-A char- acteristic and striking instance of the broad- mindedness which England always shows to her subjects, whatever be their race or colour, is the fact that Mustapha Pasha Kamel organizers in London in broad daylight the movement of destined, if his hopes are realized, to give Egypt to the Egyptians and to drive away the 1 English officials.

The "Daily Graphic" remarks:-Pan-Islam- ism is not resented in this country as an anti- British movement, but solely because it is in its practical bearing on Egyptian politics a treason against progress and civilisation. It is also- and Mastaphs Kamel would do well to note this-a treason against Egyptian Nationalism itself.
The rumor that the Pasha had become a German subject is contradicted, as such a naturalisation would be impossible under German law.

div.head: THE MOSLEM UPRISING.
div.p: Mr. Edward Dicey, in an article in the "Empire Review," expresses belief in the chronic enmity of Mohamedanism to the religion of the Cross; "but this fanatical fer- mentation does not assume serious proportions unless it is stimulated by a holy man of exceptional ability and believed--with or without reason-to be of genuine piety."

Such a man, he says, was Sheik Mahomed Ah- med of Dongola, the Mahdi of the Sudan. The memories of European residents and officials in Egypt are so short that I suspect few of them are aware how near the Mahdi came to being placed in a position enabling him to carry out his policy of marching upon Cairo and driving all Christians out of Egypt, He failed owing to the military occupation of the country by British troops. The Egyptian regiments, if not accompanied by British troops, would have refused to fight against the Dervishes, or more probably would have deserted to the enemy, welcomed as a de- liverer by the Mhoamedan population of the Khedivial kingdom.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY.
div.p: The "Moayad's" correspondent at Stamboul reports the incarceration of Mahmoud Bey Arif, of the Wakfs Administration, in consequence of calumnious charges. The Bey had scarcely landed in Stamboul, then he intended spending the summer, when he was arrested and escorted to Galata Serai. The "Moayad" dwells on the lot of the hapless Egyptian, who, in his own country is oppressed for his attachment to the Turks, and is ignominiously treated by the latter when he happens to fall into their clutches.

div.head: ENGLISH OFFICERS FOR TURKISH SHIPS.
div.p: The London News Agency is informed that Commander Hubbard, R N.R., and Commander Dowling, R.N.R., have just been appointed captains in the Imperial Ottoman Navy, and the services of a number of English engineers have also been retained by the Sultan. The two officers were recently engaged by the Turkish Ambassador in London to take out to Constantinople the Pembroke Castle and the Helius, which had been paraphrased for the Ottoman Navy from the Union Castle Line. On their arrival, both officers were decorated by the Sultan with the Order of the Osmanieh; while the chief officers of the two ships and three engineers were given the Order of the Medjiadieh of the Fifth Class. Offers were then made 1 to Commanders Hubbard and Dowling to retain command of their respective ships with the rank of captain in the Imperial Ottoman Navy, and the engineers of each ship were also asked to retain their appointments. In each case the offer was accepted, subject to the permission of the British Government.

div.head: FASHIONABLE WEDDING
HALL KELLY.
div.p: Captain George Clifford Miller Hall, D.S.O., eR.E., of the Egyptian State Railways, Cairo, son of the late Captain W. H. Hall, R.N., was married last week at St. Mary Abbotts, Kensington, to Miss Annie B. M. Kelly, d daughter of the late Mr. Fitzroy Kelly, of

Lincoln's Inn and. Colombo, Ceylon, and of t Mrs. Fitzroy Kelly, of 7, Prince of Wales's- e Terrace, Kensington. The officiating clergy e were the Dean of Worcester, Cañon Penne- is father, vicar of St. Mary Abbot's, and the . Rev. M. S. Farmer, honorary assistant chaplain at Dresden. The musical service was rendered by the fall choir, and the chancel was decorated with groups of white flowering plants.

The bride, who was given away by her brother-in-law, Mr. Eaan-Smith, wore a beautiful gown of Brussels tissue net, over silk, draped with antique Brassels point de gaze e lace, arranged with deep flounces, which covered the skirt almost entirely. The bodice was tastefully arranged to correspond. Over an i-coronet of orange blossom, white heather, and 8 myrtle, the bride wore a veil of old Brussels n lace, lent by Lady Marten. She carried a bouquet of cream roses, white heather, and e myrtle, and her ornaments included a diamond crescent, the bridegroom's gift.

Miss Frances Clark, Miss Gordon and Miss Ommsney acted as bridesmaids, with three little girls, Miss Baan Smith, Miss Jean Templer, and Miss Doris Templer. They wore very pretty Empire dresses in white muslin, over white glacé silk, with fichas in muslin and lac, caught up with pale primrose yellow ribbons. These ribbons were looped from the- front, under the arms, and, then tied in a big bow at the back, with long floating sash ends. The grown-up bridesmaids wore hats of white trimline, trimmed with ruches of white talle, and bows of pale yellow ribbon, while the children wore hats of broderie anglaise over pale yellow silk.

The bridesmaids carried bouquets of shaded yellow roses, tied with ribbons to match, and presented by the bridegroom, who also gave to each of them a gold bar brooch, with a crescent and star set with pearls and brilliants..

Captain Midwinter, R.E., was bast man. A reception, which was numeroasly attended, was held after the ceremony at Mrs. Fitzroy Kelly's house in Kensington, and later in the day the bride and bridegroom left for Scotland, 10 where the honeymoon will be spent. The bride's travelling costume consisted of a bolero and skirt in white alpses, daintily trimmed with pale green and white silk braid, and worn with a blouse of Irish gaipure and a white crinoline 8 hat, bacomingly arranged with soft green grasses.

div.head: EGYPT AND CORNWALL
A STRANGE RELATION.
div.p: Some fifteen years ago Sir Norman Lockyer, working on similar lines to Nissen of Bonn, proved that the Egyptians carefully oriented their temples so that the rising and the setting of the stars and of the sun at certain times of the year could be watched along the temple axis by the priest in the sanctuary. Sir Norman has been carrying out similar inquiries in England, and so far as his investi- e gations have gone, they strongly suggest that the British stone circles bear a precise relationship to the Egyptian temples in the method and purpose of construction.

Sir Norman Lockyer does not pretend to have reached a complete conclusion on the matter; indeed, in an article in the "Times er he ly says that other workers must continue the inquiry and reject or establish the conclusion at which he has arrived. The suggestion is that astronomer priests familiar with e Egyptian methods began work in Cornwall e about 2300 BC. The stars they used as clock o stars were the precise equivalents of the stars d in Ursa Major and Draco used by the ancient e Egyptians, when we take into account the difference of latitude between Egypt and eBritain and the effect of the precessional movement on the declination of the star. The e same may be said of the "Morning stars" they employed, and, further, they brought the May year with them,

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN PLOVER.
div.p: h It has long been ascertained that the nesting d e habits of the Egyptian plover were peculiar, in that this bird buries its eggs in the sand bat observations have not been made to show conclusively whether this was done merely for the purposes of concealment-as grebes cover their eggs before leaving them-or whether they were deposited in a hollow covered up, and then left to hatch out by the heat of the sun, after the fashion followed by certain megapodes. The latter view is highly prob- able; but it would appear that they are not altogether abandoned to this agency, inasmuch as one or other of the parent birds seems to take it in turns to sit up on the covering the eggs during the heat of the day, to prevent L them from being baked, a very necessary precaution where the sand gets heated to such a temperature that it is almost impossible to walk on it during the middle of the day.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Marquis Salvago-Raggi: Italian Diplomatic Agent, left for Europe yesterday by the Italian. mail steamer.
Marquis di Soragna, Italian Consal, will go on leave on September 6 next.

M. Klobukowski, who is likely to succeed M. de la Boulinière as French Diplomatic Agent at Cairo, was, before entering the diplo- y matic service, a chef du cabinet de préfet and I collaborator of M. Charles Thomson in the goverror-general-hip of Indo-China. He began his diplomatic career in 1889 as Consul at d Yokohama, afterwards became Consul General at Calcutta, then Minister at Bangkok and at Lima, where he now is.

Lady Cromer's brother, the Marquis of Bath, has quite won the hearts of the villagers of Horningsbam, on the borders of Longest Park. e The chapel -a quaint old thatched one- is supposed to be the oldest Nonconformist place of worship in England, for it has over its entrance ls the date 1566. It is situated near a wood a locally known as "Heaven's Gate," being the spot whence Bishop Ken wrote the "Evening Hymn." Lord Bath has given a new burial ground, besides thoroughly repairing the old thatch, and completely renovating the interior at his own expense.
Saba Pasha, Postmaster-General, left for Cairo to day by the evening express
The Very Rev. Dean and Mrs. Butcher left Cairo today for the Engadine where they will spend several weeks.

Several Italian papers have stated that er Com. Zeppa, the Italian Commissioner of the Caisse de la Dette, would be replaced by Senator Adamoli. The "Progrès," however, is d in a position to state that Com, Zeppa will O continue to fulfill his mandate until its expiration in February, 1907. It is also possible that the Italian Government will not appoint a successor.
M. Dreuilhe, French Vice-Consal at Constantinople, has been appointed to a similar post at Alexandria, to replace M. Revelli.
The Ministry of Justice has appointed hAhmed Bey Abdel Razik, judge in the Native e Tribunal of Cairo, as judge for the Markaz 3 Courts of Alexandria during this month.
Mr. Charles Baehler is on a motor tour in the Vosges district, and is on bis way to Lucerne. He will probably return to Egypt in September.

We much regret to announce the death of Miss Dorothy Ramsay Draper, the only child er, of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Draper, of the Delta an, Barrage. The child was only eight months old, and had been suffering for the last three months from acute enteritis. She was sent to Mex to get better, but the disease reached an acute stage, and she died at 4.80 yesterday ry. afternoon at Mill House, Mex.
Major-General Wykeham Leigh Pemberton, la- C.B., has been appointed Colonel Commandant, he the King's Royal Rifle Corps, vice Major- General R. W. Hinxman, deceased.

Leave of absence on private affairs has been on- granted to Lieat. Col. E.R.O. Ladlow, A.8.C., from 7th to 27th inst., and to Lieut. W.R. g- Meredith, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling with Fusiliers, from 11th inst. to September 29.
Lieut. A. Broadhurst-Hill, let Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, has been granted an extension of his leave, on the recommendation of a medical board, from 13th inst. to October 30.
Lieut. T.C. Canningham, R.A. (4th Class ay Ordnance Officer and late Inspecting Ordnance Officer of the Command), has been posted to a home station and will not return to Egypt.
The French newspapers announce the death of M. Luigini, chef-d'orchestre of the Opéra ar, Comique, who was well-known in Egypt.

div.head: LA VIERGE DE DENCHAWI
div.p: On sait que la brochure qui porte ce titre a été publiée dans l'intention évidente de oréer de l'agitation parmi la popalation indigène. Voici le résumé de l'œuvre, tel que le donne un de nos confrères:

Le cadre de l'action est le village de Den- chawi et les péripéties se déroulent dans une période quelque peu antérieure à l'aggression da 13 jain et allant jusqu'au jour de l'exécu- tion des coupables.

Un prétendant, Ahmed Zayed, se pose en concurrent de Mohamed-el-Abd, mais ne par- vient pas à supplanter celui-ci dans le cœur de Set-el-Dar. Il prie, il supplie, mais il menace aussi, et devant l'indifférence de la Vierge, i! dénonce Hassan Mahfous comme un des pr miers agresseurs des officiers anglais.
Hassan Mahfouz est condamné à mort; et il est exécuté devant Set-el Dar qui tombe évanouie dans les bras de son fiancé.
Tel est le thème du roman, on voit que le scénario n'en est pas bien compliqué.
Dans un des premiers tableaux, nous as- sistons à une réunion des villageois de Den- chawi, réunion qui eut lieu le 7 juin.

La conversation roule sur les pigeons, sur la conduite des officiers anglais durant l'année dernière vis-à-vis des pigeonniers et sur les déga's qui en sont résultés. On discate les mesures à prendre pour prévenir tonte chasse aux pigeons.

Chacun émet une idée. L'un vent laisser aller les choses à la volonté de Dieu: un autre vent prévenir à temps les autorités, à quoi un troisième répond: "Prévenir qui ? qui pourra jamais dire aux Anglais combien fait le tiers de trois?
Dans une autre scène, l'auteur décrit en termes satiriques, ce qu'il appelle la faite à travers champs du capitaine Ballcek.
Ce passage dont la grossièreté est égale à la bêtise de celui qui l'a écrit, représente l'honorable officier anglais dans une attitude des plus grotesquee.

Le capitaine fuit, il porte ses décorations sur son dolman, mais dans sa faite són pantalon est tombé, il est done presque no, car les Anglais ne portent pas de caleçon, ajouté l'auteur de cette injurieuse ineptie.
Ce passage est destiné à ridicaliser l'armée anglaise aux yeux des indigènes, afin de lui enlever tout prestige.
Ensuite nous assistons, à l'Agence Britanni- que, à une conversation entre le comte de Cromer et M. Machell.
MACHELL-Un malheur ! Seigneurie.
CROMER-Un malheur ! De quoi s'agit-il ? MACHELL-Notre honnenr militaire est terni. Le capitaine Ball est tué et d'autres officiers sont blessés.
CROMER-Et alors qu'as-tu fait?

MACHELL Je suis vena vous consulter. CROMER-(Fronçant les sourcils) Malheur aux assassins! Envoie des batteries et tout ce qu'il faut pour brûler la ville avec ses habi- tants et ses bestiaux. Mais dis-moi, où est cette ville?
MACHELL-Dans la moudirieh de Menoufieb, elle s'appelle Denchawi.
CROMER-Raconte-moi en détail ce qui s'est
passé.
(M. Machell et le comte de Cromer restent, à causer, pendant deux heures, au bout des- quelles ce dernier continue en s'adressant à M. Machell.)

"N'oublie pas de frapper deax coups à la nation égyptienne: d'abord la nomination de Helbawi bey en qualité de procureur général. puis la sévérité da jugement. Va et ordonne. aux ministres du gouvernement égyptien d'ins- tituer le tribanal spécial.
L'auteur nous transporte cette fois, su tri- bunal spécial de Chebin-el-Kom, il nous montre le président empressé auprès des efficiers an- glais.

Nous voyons, peu de temps avant le verdict, dans la salle des délibérations, le président lissut la sentence qu'on lui a imposés et dont il demande la ratification aux autres membres da tribunal spécial.
La sentence est rendue. La potence se dresse, Hassan Mahfouz est penda sans que son fils ait la permission de s'approcher de son père pour en recevoir les suprêmes déclarations.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)
Le relèvement de la cote qui se produit de- pais deux ou trois jours n'a fait aujourd'hui que s'accentuer.
Ce sont les Delta Land, le Comptoir, la Ben- que Nationale et les Nangovich Hotels qui ont eu les honneurs de la matinée.
Les Delta Land s'inscrivent à 3 9/16, comme
hier.
Quant au Comptoir, l'action ancienne réactionne à 6 21/32, et la nouvelle à 6 1/2, en perte de 1/16 sur les derniers cours, tandis que la part de fondateur s'avance, au contraire, de 45 à 46 livres.
Très ferme, l'Union Foncière clôture ache-
teurs à 6 7/32. L'Agricole gagne 1/16 à 9 25/32, la National Bank 3/16 à 26, et l'Obligation Crédit Foncier Egyptien 2 f. 50 à 337.
Mais où la reprise est la plus sensible c'est
sur les Nangovich dont le prix monte de 16 1/4 à 17-17 1/8.
Les Estates ont également donné lieu à un fort mouvement à 1 7/8. La part de fondateur finit à 10 3/4.
En somme, marché ferme et en bonne ten- dance.
Nous sommes autorisés à annoncer que Mr. Montage Summers a donné sa démission de membre de conseil d'Administration de Walker and Meimaraobi Limited.
Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
Le Caire, Jendi 9 Août 1906.

Hier, à Londres, le Consolidé anglais a en- core gagné 1/4 de livre à 88 1/4. Par contre, l'Unifiée a perdu 1/4 à 104 3/8. La National Bank est restée invariée à 25 1/2, de même que l'Agricole à 9 5/8, la Dira à 16 7/8 et la Delta Light à 11 1/2.
A Paris, l'Action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a elôturé en reprise de 1 franc à 758. La Banque d'Athènes a perdo 3 francs à 146.

Ici nous avons eu, ce matin, une séance exceptionnellement bonne, étant donné surtout, que la morte saison bat son plein. Dès le début, le marché, influencé par l'amélioration de la situation monétaire et politique en Europe, a manifesté d'excellentes dispositions; il a montré une animation et une activité qui rappelaient, par moments, les meilleures journées d'hiver Les transactions ont été nombreuses et importantes, et il y a à enregistrer des plus-values notables dans tous les compartiments.

La National Bank a gagné environ 1/4 à 25 11/16-3/4. L'Agricole a avancé à 9.3/4. La Cassi di Sconto s'est inscrite à 224-225 l'action ancienne et 213 la nouvelle. Le Comptoir Financier a progressé à 6 3/4-13/16 l'action ancienne et 6 9/16-5/8 la nouvelle.

L'action Crédit Foncier a été traitée à 757- 758; l'obligation à lots ancienne a bécéficié de 4 francs à 336. L'action Wardan Estate a réactionné à 6 7/8; la part de fondateur a, par contre, avancé à 7 3/8. La Nile Land s'est raffermie à 13 1/8 et les Improvements à 4 7/8.
Ea bonne demande, l'action Entreprises Im- mobilières et Trava 1x a avancé à 4 1/4 et la part de fondateur à 70. L'action Allotment s'est consolidée à 3 3/8-7/16 et la part de fon- dateur à 126.

Les actions Héliopolis ont été recherchées à 296 et la part de fondateur à 9. Les Automobiles ont atteint 5 13/16 et la part de fondatear 10 3/4-7/8. La part de dividende Brasserie des Pyramides est revenue à 67.
Les actions de capital Esax du Caire ont faibli à 122-123 et les Jouissances à 263-264. Le Ramleh a été coté 7 5/16-3/8.
Dans le groupe des valeurs bôtelières, les Nangovich ont été poussés à 16 3/8-7/16. Les Egyptian ont bénéficié de non moins de 1/4 de livre à 6 1/8, Les Upper Egypt ont progressé à 4 7/8.

Parmi les petites valears, grand mouvement sur les Delta Land, qui ont gagné environ 1/4 de livre à 3 9/ 6-5/8. Les Estates ont été échangés à 1 7/8; la part de fondateur a fait 10 3/4. Les Salt and Soda ont été offerts à 20 sh. 3.
On annonce de Constantinople que la Barque de Salonique est en instance auprès da gou- vernement ture pourobtenir l'autorisation de porter éventuellement son capital de 8 à 20 millions de francs.
Nous détachons d'une lettre de Londres, arrivée par le courrier d'hier soir, les lignes suivantes :

"Les tendances du Stock Exchange deviennent meilleures, et l'on prévoit une reprise sur le Consolidé ainsi que sur d'autres valeure. Sur le marché monétaire, le taux de l'escompte promet de fléchir bientôt à 3%. Les Etats-Unis ont cessé de demander de l'argent, pour le moment du moins; il ne faut pas, en effet, perdre de vue les grands besoins de l'automne ea l'Amérique à l'époque de la moisson. D'autres pays sont dans ce cas, notamment l'Egypte. Aussi bien, malgré l'aisance relative actuelle, il n'y a pas lieu de s'endormir dans une quiétude parfaite."
Les recettes des Tramwaya d'Alexandrie pour la semaine au 4 Août courant se sont élevées à L. E. 2,003 contre 1,706 en 1905, soit un surplus de L. E. 297.

Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Janvier 1906 atteignent la somme de L. E. 45,947 contre 38,817 pour la période correspondante de 1905, soit une plus-value de L. E. 7,130 en faveur de l'exercice courant.
Le mouvement de hausse qui s'était produit, ces jours derniers, sur les actions de l'Alexandra Railway Co., s'est accentué : le cours a passé de 6 7/8 à 7 7/16-3/8.

Les recettes de la semaine au 4 Août courant se sont chiffrées par L. E. 1,661 contre 1,374 en 1905, soit une augmentation de L. E. 287. Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Octobre 1905 se sont élevées à L. E. 51,056 contre 40,885 en 1905, soit un surplus de L. E. 10,171 en faveur de l'exercice courant.
Les recttes des Egyptian Markets pour la semaine au 26 Juillet dernier ont été de L. E. 463 contre 451 en 1905, c'est à dire avec un surplus de L. E. 12.
Les recettes totales depuis le commencement de l'exercice se sont élevées à L. E. 21,723 contre 15,526 soit avec une plus value de L. E 6,197.

AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat a l'honneur d'informer le public qu'à l'instar 6 de l'année dernière elle a reconeilli dans un livret spécial le Tarif qui sera mis en vigueur darant la prochaine saison cotonnière 1906-907 tpour le transport du coton (égrené et pressé hydrauliquement ou à la vapear, et non égrené) - ainsi que des graines de coton..

Ea vae d'augmenter les facilités réalisées par ce Tarif, une légère modification est intro- doite au tarif da coton non égrené taxé par sac. En effet, pendant la saison dernière la tixe par sac était établie sur la base de 225 kg. meis le poids des sacs n'ayant pas excédé 200 kg. ainsi qu'il a été constaté, c'est sur ce poids que la taxe a été basée dans le présent Tarif.

A cet avantage pour les négociants qui expé- -dient leurs cotons non égrenés par sac se joint celai d'être dispensés de présenter des états des poids détaillés de leurs expéditions et ils bénéficieront d'un délai de grå se de 96 heares eau lieu de 48.

Le livret dont il est question va être inces samment envoyé à tous les négociants de coton connus ainsi qu'aax Gares et pourra être en- voyé gratis à tous ceux qui en feront la de- mande à Mr. le Directe ir da Service des Mar #chandises au Caire..
Le Caire, le 9 Août 1906.

div.head: EDUCATION BILL.
div.p: UNEXPECTED DEVELOPMENT.
WILL THE BILL BE DROPPED?
LONDON, August 9.

The greatest importance is attached to the judgment just given by the Court of Appeal that the Education Act of 1902 does not oblige the local authorities to pay teachers for giving religions instruction in schools which are not provided by the Government.

In view of this judgment passive resisters declare that their campaign was fully justified. Liberal papers ray that it does not matter much now what the House of Lords may do with the Education Bill. (Router)
LONDON, August 9.

The new development in the Education controversy is universally discussed. A final appeal will probably be made to the House of Lords, but meanwhile there is a general feeling that the judgment of the Court of Appeal paves the way for a settlement, the present Bill being dropped in favour of a new measure dealing only with the position of teachers.
Mr. Lloyd-George, speaking at Wrexham, said that a measure dealing with the dia estab lishment and dis endowment of the Welsh Church would be passed before Parliament was -ended. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN REVOLUTION.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, August 9.
The Government has begun the struggle with the revolutionaries. A large number of raids, seizures, and arrests have been made.
(Havas)

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE.
THE PAST HALF YEAR RETURNS.
A NEW RECORD.
div.p: With the publication of the Customs re- turns for June, it is possible for us to examine the trade of the country during the first, six months of the current year, and to compare the same, with the turnover in 1905.

In dealing last August with the question of trade during the first half of 1905, we had to record a shrinkage when compared with the same period in 1904./ This decrease, for which the enormous expansion in the country's trade during the earlier months of 1904 was responsible, has now been entirely wiped away, and a new record created, viz: a total turn- over of over L.E. 21,000,000.

TA glance at the above returns shows the phenomenal growth of trade daring the past six months. Roughly speaking, the gain was one of a million in imports, and a million and a half in exports, the actual figures being L.E. 1,086,293 or 11.5% in purchases, and L.E. 1,544,708 or 16% in sales.
EXPORTS.

Although the number of cantars of cotton shipped abroad during the period under revi sion was 3,021,003 against 3,153,765 last year, the higher price clearly explain the increase of L.B. 1,928,420 in the export value.

In passing, we may just mention that from the 1st September 1905- when the present cotton season commenced-to the 29th June, the arrivals in Alexandria were 5,870,826 cantars, against 6,199,801 last season. The stceks in hand on the latter date were 568,873 eautars, whereas they were 1,010,134 cantars at the end of June 1905.
Cotton Seed.

The total cotton seed returns for the half year amounted to 1,497,726 ardebs yalued at LE. 863 285, against 1,581,445 ardeba (L.E 759,203) last year. There has thus been a loss of 83,719 ardebs but an iperesse in value of LE. 104,082. Germany has now become a buyer in this market, she having taken 98,500 ardebs in the six months in question, whereas her purchases last year during the same period were nil. The shipments to France have fallen from 66,771 ardebs to 34,646 ardebs.
Onions

Compared with 1905, the exports during the first six months of 1906 decreased by over 30,000 tons, the figures for the two years being 111,442 tons (L.E. 390,050) and 80,094 tons (LE. 215,770) respectively. It will be seen that the average price per ton has dropped nearly LE. 1 this year.
Rice.
The increase in the exports of rice since the 1st January was one of nearly 2,000,000 kilo- grams, the value of the shipments being L.B. 71,565 against L.E. 68,736 in 1905.
Gum.
The gum returns at 3,844,881 ki'ograms valued at L E. 76 808 show a loss of 698,516 kilos L.E. 28,680 on the six months.
Eggs.

The number of eggs shipped abroad during ) the period 1st January to 30th Jane was over 3,000,000 in excess of the figures for 1905. It is satisfactory to note that the average price per 1,000 eggs was much higher than last year
Cotton Cake.
A slightly larger trade was done in this article, the shipments being 38,931 tons = LE 124,591, against 35,499 tons = L.B. 113,591 during the first half of 1905.
Beans.

The member who kindly supplies our notes on beans each month has regularly this year referred to the stagnation in the export market owing to the operation of a "corner" here. Ta what extent the export trade has suffered during the six months may be gathered from the fact that the Customs returns were only 8,565 ardebs=L.E. 7,85) compared with 20,476 L.B. 141.033 for the same period last year.
-Cigarettes.

The exports of Egyptian cigarettes still continue to move in an upward direction, though we are afraid that the returns for the current halt year may be adversely affected by the recent 0. German tariff. The increase during the last six months was 16,888 kilograms.

Great Britain was, of course, Egypt's best customer daring the period under revision, her 30 purchases of L.E. 5,497,358 or 49.2% of the total export trade being almost the same figure 10. as in 1905. Germany increased her share from 9% to 10.8% France retained the 3rd position with 8% against 8. 9%. Russia took goods to the value of LE 741,143 or 6.6%, being an improvement on her figures of L.B. 499,614 (5.2%) for the first half of 1905, American dropped from 6.2% to 5.5% while Austria increased her returns from 5.4% to 5 8% by The shipments to India shows large abri kage being, in point of fact, only L.E 52,914 against pe L.E. 186,903.

div.head: EGYPT'S DANGER.
THE MONEY CURSE AND THE FELLAH.
INDIAN OPINION.
div.p: The "Times of India" (Bombay, July 14):- The grave statement upon the condition of Egypt made by Sir Edward Grey in the House of Commons has officially unfolded the reali- ties of a situation which those cognisant of the inner movement of events have been aware of for a considerable time past.

The situation which Sir Edward Grey revealed is due to a variety of causes. Prominent among these is the phenomenal prosperity of Egypt. Its rapidly increasing wealth is in some respects proving a curse instead of a blessing. The fellaheen had themselves in a position to which for centuries they have been stran- gers. Life is secure, forced labour has been abolished, taxation is moderate, oppression has disappeared, and new and unwanted freedom and liberty is everywhere permitted. They get high prices for their crops, and their money is safe from the extortion of officials. The larger landholders, of whom there are many, have rapidly risen to extreme affluence. The natives of the country, both aristocrats and cultivators, have got more money than they know what to do with. For a parallel we must turn to the ryots of the Deccan in the halcyon days of the American Civil War, when they bound the wheels of their carts with silver. One result of this super- abundance of money is the mad speculation in land values in and around Cairo ; another and more serious consequence is that the stalled ox, having waxed fat, is kicking. The super: abundance of wealth has turned the heads of the people. They forget the maddening exactions of the days of Jemail, the grinding indigence of Tewfik's rale, the anarchy of the days of Arabi, the cynical extravagance and the gross travesty of good government that lasted through so many decades, 4 new A generation has arisen that has no bitter memories of the past, that accepts the existing order as a natural environment for which no gratitude need be felt, that listens with greedy alacrity to the whispers of mischief- makers. Into this receptive soil is constantly poured the flowing assurances of secret agents from Constantinople, for if we would trace the Causes of unrest in Egypt to their source, we must look, among other directions, towards Yild'z Kiosk. Again, it is probable that Cairo as it exists today exercises a some- what unwholesome influence over the whole of Egypt. It is not only that the hordes of European tourists who visit the capital frequently inspire the reverse of respect in the native population, while they set a standard of extravagant living which the wealthier Egyp- tians ardently seek to emulate. A deeper issue is that in the winter Cairo has become the resort of large numbers of persons who represent the seamier side of European life, to whose allurements many of the better class of native residents fall willing victims. These tendencies help to explain the retrogressive situation in Egypt, and it is to that caus", among others, that is due the fact that the younger generation of Egyptians of good birth is turning out so few administrators with any real capacity. They seek their education in Paris or Vienna, they acquire many habits not in their curriculum, and when they enter the public service on their return to their native land they too often degenerate into haunters of cafés; and the cafés of Cairo and Alexandria are breeding- grounds of disorder and intrigue. Of course there are many notable exceptions, but it is a regrettable fact, that, speaking broadly, the New Egypt is not producing that class of high- minded and able native civil servants which at one time it was hoped would be created. Beyond all these causes, but probably more important than all the rest, because it is so elusive, lies the mysterious and subtle effects of that vagne and yet definite Pan-Islamic movement, which is far more visible in Africa than in Asia, which is felt from the Sinaitic Peninsula to the borders of Tunis, which is equally traceable in outbreaks in the swampy receses of Lake Chad and in the Nilotie delta. All that the Pan-Islamic movement Hportends cannot yet be perceived, but it is plain from Sir Edward Grey's guarded state- ment that it has some connection with the unrest in Egypt, and it is equally manifest that we must be prepared at any moment for such a recrudescence of fanaticism along the Nile as may necessitate the pouring of rein- forcements into the country......It seems to be the fate of the Briton in the Orient to be for ever rolling stones uphill."

div.head: AFRICAN TRADE ROUTES.
div.p: Trade routes in Africa are a most difficult problem, and upon the isolation of them hang many others. At present, as far as France is concerned, it costs £80 to transport a ton of goods from Bordeaux to Fort Lamy, on Lake Chad, by the Congo and Ubanghi route. There has since been discovered, through the efforts of the Faure Audoin mission, a route by which it is hope I the cost will be reduced per ton to about £20. This route is by the Niger Benove and Logone,, and the time of transit from Bordeaux to Chad would be about 50 days. Still third route is engaging attention by the Niger and the Senegal rivers, which would have the advantage of being all French, and would do away with native porterage altogether. A scientific mission, subsidized by the Government and the French Geographical Society, leaver rs France shortly to study these questions or the spot.

div.head: GERMAN FOREIGN POLICY.
INFLUENCE OF THE RUSSIAN CRISIS
div.p: Professor Dalbrück, discussing in the "Preussische Jahrbücher" the effect of the Russian crisis on German foreign policy, expresses conviction that years of ferment may be expected to elapse before any practical working agreement is evolved between the Government of the Emperor Nicholas and the people. This means that as an international factor Russia may be largely eliminated from the calculations of Berlin, since it will be out of the power of Russia either to prove dangerous or to act as & support to Germany..

"Consequently," observes the Professor, "the Triple Alliance may be regarded as likely, to become superfluous except in so far as it pre- serves peace between Italy and Austria. In the future the alliance with Austria is the only one which Germany, for her own sake, need be concerned to cultivate by every means at her disposal. For Austria alone of all Powers is prompted by her own interests to go hand-in- hand with Germany towards the main goal which the policy of Berlin has and must have in view, the acquisition of influence in the Mohammedan world"

Professor Delbrück observes that Great Britain, France, Russia, and to a certain degree Italy, are the natural opponents of Germany in this her great aim which, he remarks in pa- renthesis, does not signify a desire for the acquisition of land. The recent negotiations relating to the Bagdad Railway and to the in- crease of Turkish Customs which is said to be associated with that undertaking, have shown afresh, in Professor Delbrück's view,how terribly difficult it is for Germany to advance along her appointed path. German influence, in fact, is combated in common by all the other Powers, for in the eyes of those Powers the German Empire is already too powerful.

With some emphasis Professor Delbrück affirms that there exists no more perilous situation than this in the game of international politics, and he argues that the Imperial Government deserves not blame from the nation, but high praise on account of the extreme caution with which it strides onwards.

div.head: MOSLEM FEMALE EDUCATION.
div.p: Briefly but pointedly the Calcatta "Malk and Millut" ("Country and People") deplores the average Mahometan lady's lack of education. In these days, says the journal, when so much is said and written about education and training colleges for females in this part of India, it is interesting to note that in Turkey there are 1,000 schools in which girls receive education. There are forty secondary schools having 3,000 girls on their rolls. The learning of Quran is compulsory, and arithmetic, geography, and elementary science are taught. Teaching has now become a respectable profession, and young ladies after passing the normal examinations, elect to become tutoresses in distant parts of the Empire. Those who are in a position to prosecute their studies to the higher standard, learn French, English, and German languages, which they speak fluently. In Constantinople, young ladies go up for medical profession, and there are over three hundred nurses at the present day. Female education is not an innovation among the Mahometans of the present day. The Arab and Moorish women in their palmy days, when their European sisters were steeped in ignorance, would deliver sermons and would profess in colleges and schools. The present deplorable position of the Mahometan females is due to the general degradation of the nation. An Awakening, however, is now taking place in some parts of the Mahometan world, and the day may possibly dawn again when the stain of ignorance may be wiped off from the Mahometan ladies of this country with the help of the Government.

div.head: CYPRUS GYPSUM.
div.p: An important addition has been made to the industrial potentialities of Cyprus by the establishment of the "Adelphotis" gypsum factory and steam flour mill at Limassol,on the mainroad from Nicosia, a mile outside Limassol.

The gypsum stone is brought from quarries at Moutayiaka 3 miles distant and from Ay- Athanasios 2 miles distant. There are 4 ovens in all, of which three are heated by brushwood and hold 40 tons, and the other is heated by coal and contains 20 tons. The stone remains some 8 to 10 hours under heat. The disintegrator turns out 40 tons of finished gypsum per diem, this being filled into sacks at 40 okes per sack. This nearly all finds a market in Egypt.

The factory has been open for work since the end of January, and finds employment for 60 to 70 hands. The manager and engi- neer is Mr. Zeno Skyrianides, who had experience both in Cyprus and Egypt. It is believed that there is an ample water supply for all the needs of the factory.

The capital of the company is £5,000, and having regard to the large market for gypsum in Egypt, and the demands that exist both in and out of the island for flour of fine quality, the company should have a successful future.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS.
div.p: NOTICE.

The Egyptian State Railways hereby gives notice to the public that the Adminis tration requires 40 pupils-20 from Upper Egypt and 20 from Lower Egypt-who will be trailed for the traffic service with a view to to their being appointed to station duties in Upper or Lower Egypt. Competitive examina-C tion for the admission of papils to fill these vacancies will be held on and after the 1st September, 1906, before a Special Commission at Assiout Railway Station for those of Upper Egypt, and at Cairo for those of Lower Egypt. Candidates must falfil the following condi- tions:-
1st-They must be of Egyptian nationality;
2nd-They must be of good character;
3rd-They must possess the primary certificate of education of a date not previous to 1903;
4th-They must be medically fit for railway service;
5th They must be between the age of 18 and 22 years;
8th-If during the period of apprenticeship pupils do not give satisfaction, they will be dismissed and will not have the right to any claim whatever;

9th-Candidates attending the examination will pay the railway fare either to assist or to Cairo. Those, however, who are afterwards accepted will be granted a free pass to the place where they are sent for their apprenticeship.
Candidates desirous of attending the above examination. are required to send their names to the Traffic Manager, before 26th August proximo, enclosing at the same time the following certificates:
1-A certificate of good conduct signed by the Mamour of their district and the Omdeh of their parish;
2-The customary guarantees;
3-Those from Upper Egypt should produce certificates that they actually belong to Upper Egypt, and those of Lower Egypt should get certificates that they belong to Lower Egypt.
On the production of the above, their names will be recorded and an entrance card sent to them by the Traffic Manager.

Candidates presenting themselves at the place of examination will first of all be required to undergo an examination as to medical fitness, and not be allowed to proceed further with the examination unless they qualify in this.
The 40 candidates, who in the opinion of the Board of Examination are the best fitted as regards character and both physical and mental acquirements, will be appointed élèves of the Administration.

div.p: CAIRO-ALEXANDRIA TELEPHONE.--Rates as follows P.T. 5 for each 3 minutes, or fraction of 3 minutes; P.T. 10 for over 3 up to 8 minutes communication.

PUBLIC CALL-OFFICES : Cairo, Central Office, Opera Square, and New Bar; Helouan, Central Office, Maison Purvis ; Alexandria, St Mark's Buildings, Egyptian Bar, I. Castelli & Co.; Ramleh, Central Office. San Stefano Casino 30.4.906

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
